title: Are GMOs good or bad?

multiple-choice.question: What is the primary difference between selective breeding and genetic engineering?

options.label: A
options.text: Selective breeding is more precise, while genetic engineering is more random.

options.label: B
options.text: Selective breeding is more random, while genetic engineering is more precise.

options.label: C
options.text: Selective breeding is used for plants, while genetic engineering is used for animals.

options.label: D
options.text: Selective breeding is used for animals, while genetic engineering is used for plants.

options.label: A
options.text: To produce more resilient crops

options.label: B

options.label: C
options.text: To prevent the unintentional spreading of engineered DNA

options.label: D
options.text: To reduce pesticide use

options.label: B
options.text: Eating GMO plants is no more risky than eating non-GMO plants

options.label: C
options.text: The safety of eating GMO plants is still unknown

options.label: D
options.text: Eating GMO plants is completely risk-free

options.text: They are more resistant to pests

options.label: C
options.text: They are more nutritious

options.label: D

options.text: Producing more meat

options.label: B
options.text: Producing more resilient crops

options.label: C

options.label: D

options.text: The protagonist's journey ends in a point of no return.

multiple-choice.question: Who was Oisín's love interest in the story, and what was her background?

options.text: Niamh, an immortal princess from Tír na nÓg.

options.label: C
options.text: Fionn, a warrior from the Fianna.

options.label: D
options.text: A goddess from Ancient Ireland.

multiple-choice.question: What was the nature of time in Tír na nÓg, the land of youth?

options.label: A

options.label: B

options.label: C
options.text: Time moved quickly, and the people aged rapidly.

options.label: D
options.text: Time was irrelevant, and the people lived forever.

multiple-choice.question: What was the warning given to Oisín by Niamh before he returned to Ireland?

options.label: A
options.text: He must not speak to anyone from his past.

options.label: B
options.text: He must not alight from his horse to touch the earth with his own feet.

options.label: C
options.text: He must not look back at Tír na nÓg.

options.label: D
options.text: He must not reveal his true identity.

multiple-choice.question: What was the consequence of Oisín's return to mortal lands after being in Tír na nÓg?

options.label: A
options.text: He was rejuvenated and regained his youth.

options.label: B
options.text: He was unaffected by the passage of time.

options.label: C
options.text: He was aged irreversibly and became an old man.

options.label: D
options.text: He was transformed into a god.

options.label: B

options.label: D
options.text: Charon, the ferry captain

multiple-choice.question: What was the condition given by Hades and Persephone for Orpheus to take Eurydice back to the world of the living?

options.label: A
options.text: Orpheus had to sing a song for them every day

options.label: B
options.text: Orpheus had to bring a gift for the rulers of the underworld

options.label: C
options.text: Orpheus must not turn around to see if Eurydice was following behind him

options.label: D
options.text: Orpheus had to stay in the underworld forever

multiple-choice.question: What happened to Orpheus when he tried to return to the underworld after being separated from Eurydice again?

options.label: A
options.text: He was welcomed back by Hades and Persephone

options.label: B
options.text: He was refused entry to the underworld

options.label: C
options.text: He was given a second chance to take Eurydice back to the world of the living

options.label: D
options.text: He was turned into a stone

multiple-choice.question: Who were the Maenads, and why did they destroy Orpheus?

options.label: A
options.text: The Maenads were a group of wild women who were jealous of Orpheus's love for Eurydice

options.label: B
options.text: The Maenads were a group of wild women who were angry at Orpheus for not loving them

options.label: C
options.text: The Maenads were a group of goddesses who were punishing Orpheus for his disobedience

options.label: D
options.text: The Maenads were a group of monsters who were afraid of Orpheus's music

multiple-choice.question: What art form was born out of Orpheus's love and loss, according to the story?

options.label: A
options.text: The epic poem

options.label: B
options.text: The love poem

options.label: C
options.text: The tragedy

options.label: D
options.text: The comedy

title: How does the immune system work? - Emma Bryce

multiple-choice.question: What is the main function of the immune system in the human body?

options.label: A
options.text: To regulate body temperature

options.label: B
options.text: To aid in the digestion of food

options.label: C
options.text: To safeguard against infection, illness, and disease

options.label: D
options.text: To produce hormones

multiple-choice.question: What are the molecular traces on the surface of pathogens and other foreign substances called?

options.label: A
options.text: Antibodies

options.label: B
options.text: Antigens

options.label: C
options.text: Leukocytes

options.label: D
options.text: Phagocytes

multiple-choice.question: Which type of leukocytes trigger the immune response by sending macrophages and dendritic cells into the blood?

options.label: A
options.text: Lymphocytes

options.label: B
options.text: Phagocytes

options.label: C
options.text: T-cells

options.label: D
options.text: B-cells

multiple-choice.question: What is the purpose of the high temperatures and swelling that occur during an immune response?

options.label: A
options.text: To aid the reproduction and spread of bacteria and viruses

options.label: B
options.text: To attract phagocytes and aid the immune response

options.label: C
options.text: To neutralize the production of antibodies

options.label: D
options.text: To reduce the number of leukocytes in the body

multiple-choice.question: What is the result of the immune system's constant surveillance over time?

options.label: A
options.text: The development of autoimmune diseases

options.label: B
options.text: The reduction of leukocytes in the body

options.label: C
options.text: The neutralization of the immune response

options.label: D
options.text: The development of long-term immunity

title: Why should you read Charles Dickens? - Iseult Gillespie

multiple-choice.question: What is a notable feature of Charles Dickens's writing style?

options.label: A
options.text: His use of simplistic settings and straightforward plotlines.

options.label: B
options.text: His emphasis on romantic relationships and happy endings.

options.label: C
options.text: His use of brooding settings, plot twists, and mysteries to create anticipation.

options.label: D
options.text: His focus on the lives of the wealthy and privileged.

multiple-choice.question: How were Charles Dickens's stories initially published?

options.label: A
options.text: As complete books.

options.label: B
options.text: As serialized chapters in literary journals.

options.label: C
options.text: As adaptations for the stage.

options.label: D
options.text: As illustrated novels.

multiple-choice.question: What is a common theme in Charles Dickens's works, influenced by his own childhood experiences?

options.label: A
options.text: The struggles of the upper class.

options.label: B
options.text: The impact of the Industrial Revolution on the lower classes.

options.label: C
options.text: The joys of country life.

options.label: D
options.text: The importance of social status.

multiple-choice.question: What is a characteristic of Charles Dickens's portrayal of London in his works?

options.label: A
options.text: A one-dimensional depiction of a purely grim and corrupt city.

options.label: B
options.text: A dualistic portrayal of a harsh world filled with wonder and possibility.

options.label: C
options.text: A focus on the city's historical landmarks and tourist attractions.

options.label: D
options.text: A complete avoidance of the city's social and economic issues.

multiple-choice.question: What is the significance of the novel "The Mystery of Edwin Drood" in Charles Dickens's body of work?

options.label: A
options.text: It is considered his greatest masterpiece.

options.label: B
options.text: It is his longest and most complex novel.

options.label: C
options.text: It is the only novel he wrote that was not serialized.

options.label: D
options.text: It is the only novel he left unfinished at the time of his death.

title: How do fish make electricity? - Eleanor Nelsen

multiple-choice.question: What is the primary function of the electrocytes in the electric organs of weakly electric fish?

options.label: A
options.text: To pump out sodium and potassium ions to maintain a positive charge outside and negative charge inside

options.label: B
options.text: To generate a strong electric discharge to stun prey

options.label: C
options.text: To detect electrical signals from other fish

options.label: D
options.text: To navigate through the water

multiple-choice.question: Which of the following is a characteristic of strongly electric fish?

options.label: A
options.text: They produce up to a volt of electricity

options.label: B
options.text: They have electroreceptors buried in their skin

options.label: C
options.text: They can produce enough electricity to attack their prey

options.label: D
options.text: They are only found in freshwater environments

multiple-choice.question: What is the purpose of the electric eel's two-phased attack when hunting prey?

options.label: A
options.text: To communicate with other electric eels

options.label: B
options.text: To navigate through the water

options.label: C
options.text: To stimulate the prey's muscles and then incapacitate it

options.label: D
options.text: To detect the shape and size of nearby objects

multiple-choice.question: Which of the following is a theory as to why electric fish do not electrocute themselves?

options.label: A
options.text: The size of strongly electric fish allows them to withstand their own shocks

options.label: B
options.text: The current passes out of their bodies too quickly

options.label: C
options.text: Special proteins shield the electric organs

options.label: D
options.text: All of the above

multiple-choice.question: What is the name of the fish that has an elongated chin called a schnauzenorgan that is riddled with electroreceptors?

options.label: A
options.text: Electric eel

options.label: B
options.text: Electric catfish

options.label: C
options.text: Electric ray

options.label: D
options.text: Peter's elephantnose fish

title: The Bystander Effect: The science of empathy

multiple-choice.question: What is the bystander effect in psychology?

options.label: A
options.text: The phenomenon where people in a group are more likely to offer help to someone in need.

options.label: B
options.text: The phenomenon where people in a group are less likely to offer help to someone in need.

options.label: C
options.text: The phenomenon where people in a group are more likely to experience empathy.

options.label: D
options.text: The phenomenon where people in a group are less likely to experience empathy.

multiple-choice.question: What is the diffusion of responsibility in the context of the bystander effect?

options.label: A
options.text: When people in a group take collective responsibility for helping someone in need.

options.label: B
options.text: When people in a group assume someone else will take responsibility for helping someone in need.

options.label: C
options.text: When people in a group are more likely to offer help to someone in need.

options.label: D
options.text: When people in a group are less likely to experience empathy.

multiple-choice.question: In the experiment described in the transcript, how long did it take for participants in a group of 10 to offer help?

options.label: A
options.text: 3 minutes and 19 seconds

options.label: B
options.text: 5 minutes and 30 seconds

options.label: C
options.text: 7 minutes and 25 seconds

options.label: D
options.text: 8 minutes and 1 second

multiple-choice.question: According to the experiment, what was the average time it took for participants who were alone to offer help?

options.label: A
options.text: 5 minutes and 30 seconds

options.label: B
options.text: 7 minutes and 25 seconds

options.label: C
options.text: 8 minutes and 1 second

options.label: D
options.text: 3 minutes and 19 seconds

multiple-choice.question: What is the main reason why people in a group are less likely to offer help to someone in need, according to the bystander effect?

options.label: A
options.text: They are less empathetic

options.label: B
options.text: They assume someone else will take responsibility

options.label: C
options.text: They are less capable of helping

options.label: D
options.text: They are more focused on their own needs

title: The myth of Prometheus - Iseult Gillespie

multiple-choice.question: What was the task entrusted to Epimetheus by Zeus?

options.label: B
options.text: To distribute the gifts of the gods among the creatures

options.label: C
options.text: To decide how sacrifices would be made to the gods

options.label: D
options.text: To steal fire from the workshop of Hephaestus and Athena

multiple-choice.question: Why did Zeus forbid the use of fire on Earth?

options.label: A
options.text: Because he wanted to punish humans for their disobedience

options.label: B
options.text: Because he wanted to protect the natural order

options.label: C
options.text: Because he was outraged at Prometheus's deception

options.text: Because he wanted to test human ingenuity

options.label: B
options.text: To be chained to a cliff for eternity and have his liver torn out by a vulture daily

options.label: C
options.text: To be forced to live among humans

options.label: D

What event in 1605 likely influenced Shakespeare's writing of "Macbeth"?

multiple-choice.question: What is the phrase that the witches chant at the beginning of the play, predicting a world gone mad?

options.label: A
options.text: "Fair is foul and foul is fair. Hover through the fog and filthy air."

options.label: B
options.text: "Double, double toil and trouble; Fire burn, and caldron bubble."

options.label: C
options.text: "Out, damned spot! Out, I say!"

options.label: D
options.text: "Life's but a walking shadow, a poor player that struts and frets his hour upon the stage."

options.label: A
options.text: "Life's but a walking shadow, a poor player that struts and frets his hour upon the stage."

options.label: B
options.text: "Out, damned spot! Out, I say!"

options.label: C
options.text: "Double, double toil and trouble; Fire burn, and caldron bubble."

options.label: D

title: Where do math symbols come from? - John David Walters

multiple-choice.question: Who is credited with inventing the equals sign (=) in mathematics?

options.label: A
options.text: Christian Kramp

options.label: B
options.text: Robert Recorde

options.label: C
options.text: Isaac Newton

options.label: D
options.text: Albert Einstein

options.label: A
options.text: It was derived from the Greek alphabet.

options.label: B
options.text: It was condensed from the Latin word "et" meaning "and".

options.label: C
options.text: It was introduced by Christian Kramp.

options.label: D
options.text: It was invented by Robert Recorde.

multiple-choice.question: What is the purpose of using symbols in mathematics?

options.label: A
options.text: To make calculations more complex.

options.label: B
options.text: To avoid repeating oneself or using a lot of words to write out mathematical ideas.

options.label: C
options.text: To confuse non-mathematicians.

options.label: D
options.text: To make mathematics more abstract.

multiple-choice.question: What does the capital sigma (Σ) symbol represent in mathematics?

options.label: A
options.text: A number multiplied by itself.

options.label: B
options.text: The repeated addition of the same number.

options.label: C
options.text: A long string of sequential terms added together.

options.label: D
options.text: The division of two numbers.

multiple-choice.question: According to the transcript, what is likely to be true about an alien civilization's mathematical symbols?

options.label: A
options.text: They would be identical to ours.

options.label: B
options.text: They would be completely different from ours.

options.label: C
options.text: They would not have any symbols at all.

options.label: D
options.text: They may correspond directly to ours, but would likely be different.
